description: Political cartoon of a crowd of black men and women, holding up large boxes labeled with "Profits for" and the logos of different companies (Marconi, Anglo American Mining, ICI, Roundtree Macintosh, B.T.R., Rio Tinto Zinc, Ford, Barclays Bank). A caricature of Margaret Thatcher with a long tail is saying to a caricature of Pik Botha as a pig dressed in a suit, "I thought you'd banned these mass funerals Pik." Smoke and fire rise in background.
title: I thought you'd banned these mass funerals Pik.

description: Thirty color photographs of a young black man, grooming, and getting dressed in a t-shirt printed with the words "H.I.V. positive". A Treatment Action Campaign poster depicting the CEO of Glaxo SmithKline South Africa appears on the wall in several of the photographs. At right is text describing the life of Bonile Peter since his diagnosis with HIV, his participation in Treatment Action Campaign activism, and his thoughts about the South African government policies on prevention of mother-to-child HIV transmission.

description: Drawing of three young children, a boy, girl, and infant inside a doorway, who look outside at a man and a woman fighting in front of the house. The children cry and cover their faces with their hands. The man has one hand outstretched and gestures toward the woman with the other. The woman points at the man with one hand and in the other holds up a long-handled spoon as if to strike him. A large pot lies between them, broken and spilling its contents onto the ground. Across the street, another person can be seen standing in a doorway, watching the fight.

description: Seven color drawings, each with some explanatory text. The drawings are labeled "talauci", a barefoot woman seated on the ground with her arms wrapped around her knees; "lafiyar uwa", a pregnant woman holding her hands behind her lower back; "zaman lafiya", a rifle and a crossbow; "matasa", a pregnant woman and a man standing with his back toward her; "muhalli", a road or pathway with sparse vegetation alongside it; "'ya mace", a baby swaddled in blankets; and "duka", a frowning man grabbing a woman by the shoulder of her blouse with one hand and holding up a stick with the other hand.
title: Abubuwan da suka shafi mata : kare hakkokin mata kullum.

notes.note: "Production of CHABELL."

description: A black and white drawing depicts Black soldiers wearing fabric hats and armed with bayonets, facing off against a line of soldiers wearing helmets and pointing rifles at them. title: British arms will make a great contribution to South Africa's way of life

description: Poster advertises a Black solidarity march at the U.N. in New York on November 5, 1979. Title at top, and photographs of Malcolm X and Martin Luther King, Jr. at left. Other photographs depict Black Americans protesting. A green, black, and red pattern is in the background. Text calls for human rights, promotes a general strike, and, next to photographs of white policemen and Ku Klux Klan members, says, "Black people charge genocide." Publication and contact information appear in the lower left corner.
title: National march at the U.N. : Black solidarity day, November 5, 1979

notes.note: National Office of National Black Human Rights Coalition

description: Black and white cartoon drawing of a young black woman wearing a school uniform standing on a road between two black men. One man, dressed in shorts and a t-shirt, stands just off the road and gestures toward the forest. The other, dressed in slacks, dress shoes, and a jacket, offers her cash and points in the direction of a road sign labeled "Muli Madyo Resthouse". She holds up a hand protectively in each direction, refusing each man. Logos for Malawi National AIDS Control Programme and the STAFH Project appear at the bottom. The poster verso includes Chewa text.

contributor.label: Malawi AIDS Control Programme
variants: Malawi. Ministry of Health. AIDS Control Programme
Malawi. Ministry of Health. National AIDS Control Programme

title: Muli Madyo Resthouse
